and Boris. He is his godson," she added, her tone suggesting that this fact ought to give Prince Vasili much satis- faction. 
Prince Vasili became thoughtful and frowned. Anna Mikhdylovna saw that he was afraid of finding in her a rival for Count Be- zukhov's fortune, and hastened to reassure him. 
"If it were not for my sincere affection and devotion to Uncle" said she, uttering the word with peculiar assurance and unconcern, "I know his character: noble, upright . . . but you see he has no on
